Docs.summary: Contains information about the changes that occur in the event.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange> object specifies where a change occurred in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBox> or <xref:System.Windows.Controls.RichTextBox>. The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange.Offset%2A> property specifies the position of the change, the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange.AddedLength%2A> property specifies how many symbols were added, and the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange.RemovedLength%2A> property specifies how many symbols were removed. When the change occurs in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBox>, a symbol is a single character. When a change occurs in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.RichTextBox>, a symbol is one of the following:
- An opening or closing tag for a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.TextElement> element.
- A <xref:System.Windows.UIElement> element contained within an <xref:System.Windows.Documents.InlineUIContainer> or <xref:System.Windows.Documents.BlockUIContainer>. Note that such a <xref:System.Windows.UIElement> is always counted as exactly one symbol; any additional content or elements contained by the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement> are not counted as symbols.
- Each 16-bit [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_unicode](~/includes/tlasharptla-unicode-md.md)] character inside of a text <xref:System.Windows.Documents.Run> element.
<xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextChange> is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5. For more information, see [Versions and Dependencies](~/docs/framework/migration-guide/versions-and-dependencies.md).
